title: arcadia-group-administration-means-shopper
story: The high street giant, which includes the Topshop, Dorothy Perkins, and Burton brands, has hired administrators from Deloitte after the pandemic ldquoseverely impacted sales across its brands.It comes as Debenhams faces liquidationafterJD Sports confirmed that discussions with the administrators of the department store chainregarding a potential acquisition of the UK business have now been terminated.Now consumers have been warned about their rights and are being urged to spend any vouchers they have immediately.Adam French, Which  consumer rights expert, said: "Topshop and other Arcadia brands collapsing into administration is yet another serious blow for the high street in what has been a torrid year for retail.ldquoWe would advise any consumers who have vouchers to think about spending them as soon as they can.ldquoIf there is something you are planning to buy from Topshop or other affected brands that is worth more than pound, make sure you use a credit card as yoursquoll be able to make a claim against your credit card company to recover the moneyanything goes wrong.Which  has produced advice for those concerned about their rights as shops become insolvent.What does going into administration mean When a company goes into administration it means it has become insolvent and will be run by an appointed administrator, who must be a licensed insolvency practitioner.The administrator will work with the insolvent firm either to save it through some form of rescue procedure like a Company Voluntary Arrangement , sell the company to a new owner, or work with the company to wind it up.If a company goes into administration, it wonrsquot necessarily mean that the company will actually go out of business or stop trading altogether. But, usually, it means yoursquoll find it more dficult to exercise your rights.This applies even where we see a rapid purchase of a company thatrsquos gone into administration, where on the surface it looks like itrsquos businesses as usual.Can Iitems to a retailer thats gone into administration It depends. Once a retailer goes into administration the administrators role is to try and save the company, and in doing so, it may take the decision not to accept s.But you could ask for a refundthe things you bought werent delivered, or you could claim for the cost of a repairthey were faulty.Do myrights still apply after a company has gone into administration If yoursquove been supplied with faulty goods and the company is placed into administration but is still trading, you may be able to get a replacement or a refund in the normal way under the Consumer Rights Act.If the company isnrsquot trading while itrsquos in administration, yoursquoll need to make a claim to the administrator as an unsecured creditor, so it may be unlikely that youll get a refund in this case.Butyou donrsquot submit a claim in writing to the administrators then it is highly unlikely that they will stand to get their money back. We think itrsquos worth at least trying.If you have a faulty item, you could register your claim with the administrators for the cost of fixing the item, or for a refundtheres still time to reject the item.Can I still use my warranty after a company has gone into administration If you bought an item thats faulty and it came with a warranty, you should be able to claim a refund or repair from the manufacturer under the terms of the warranty.You may be able to make a claim on an extended warrantythe cover was provided by a third party .If the retailer goes into administration and the goods are faulty, then your manufacturers warranty should cover you for at least the first year. Check your documentation to seethis is the case.Check the small print carefully to see who actually provided the warranty cover. Often itrsquos provided by a third partyin which case you shouldnrsquot be affecteda store ceases trading.If the cover was provided by the retailer in question, then it depends on what happens at the end of the administration period.If the retailer ceases to trade, then unfortunately you would lose the benefit of the extended warranty.Remember that youll usually get a manufacturerrsquos guarantee with an item that will provide some protection for the first year - sometimes even longer.Can I claim from my card company If you paid for goods that cost less than pound on a credit or debit card, you may be able to claim under chargeback.If youve bought something on your credit card costing more than pound, means the card provider is jointly responsible for any breaches of contract.You can claim under Section  of the Consumer Credit Actthe item is faulty.Write to your credit card company with details of your claim. You can use our template letter to claim a refund from your credit card companya retailer goes bust.Can I claimI only paid a deposit You dont have to have paid the full amount on your credit card ndash the card company is liable evenyou made only part of the paymenton your card.Its the value of the goods youre buying thats key, not the amount paid on the card.Under Section , as long as the value of the product is between pound and pound, then youll be covered, regardless of how much you paid on your card.So, for example,you ordered a new camera and paid a pound deposit with your credit card and paid the balance of pound by cheque, youd be covered for the whole poundthe company went out of business and you didnt get your camera.Can I still use my gt vouchers after a company has gone into administration A number of high street stores have refused to allow customers to use gt vouchers after going into administration. Unfortunately, this is within the law.But,the administrator takes this decision its worth waiting a few days to seeit will change its mind.If your gt vouchers are refused, you need to make a claim in writing to the administrators with proof of your vouchers.You can find the name of the administrator on the website of the retailer that has gone into administration.But theres no guarantee youll get all of your money back, and it could take up to  months to process the claim properly. And, not all administrators will take this approach.If you want to get your money back, you can use our template letter to claim a refund for vouchers from a bust company.Can I make a chargeback claim for gt vouchers If a company is accepting gt vouchers then chargeback claims will not be accepted.If gt vouchers arent being accepted and you bought gt vouchers on your card, you should be able to put in a chargeback request to your bank on the grounds that the vouchers are fundamentally dferent from what you paid for.This is because you expected to be able to exchange the vouchers for goods of a certain value and instead theyre worthless.If the vouchers were given to you as a gt, its trickier to make this argument. The person who received a voucher as a gt cant make a claim.But the person who bought the vouchers could put in a chargeback request to the bank. You can use our letter template to help you make a chargeback claim.Its worth noting though, that theres no guarantee the administrators will accept chargeback claims.Can I get my cashback If you were supposed to get cashback as part of your purchase, it depends on how the cashback offer was set up - you may still receive it.Check the terms and conditions to see whether the offer is backed by the manufacturer , or whether the cashback claim should be made to the retailer.If the manufacturer is providing the cashback, your claim shouldnt be affected.If its the retailer, you could still put in a claim and they would be in breach of contractthey didnt send the cash.If you didnt get the cash, unfortunately, you couldnt take court action against the retailer while its in administration.If at the end of the administration the retailer stopped trading, youd need to lodge your claim for unpaid cashback with the administrators.

title: coronavirus-tiers-no-changes-east-lothian-remains-level-2
story: That means neighbouring Midlothian will remain in Level  Covid restrictions for another week after the First Minister said no changes would be made this week.Speaking to the Scottish Parliament today , Nicola Sturgeon said that good progress was being made in pushing down the spread of coronavirus across Scotland.While East Lothian stays in Level , hopes that neighbouring Midlothian would join it were dashed as the First Minister saidthere was still a need to ldquostrengthen and solidy the progress made.She told MSPs: ldquoThe sacrices everyone is making are making a dference, they are getting case numbers down, reducing the numbers getting ill and needing hospital care, and so protecting the NHS and saving lives.ldquoAlthough we are encouraged by the impact current restrictions have had, the need to strengthen and solidy that progress means we should continue to take care and err on the side of caution.Ms Sturgeon said that no local authority would see a level change this week following a weekly review but indicated changes were likely to be brought in next week.That means Edinburgh also remains in Level  and West Lothian in Level .

title: 100-new-affordable-homes-delivered-east-lothian-year
story: Tenants have been collecting keys to  new council houses which East Lothian Council took ownership of in Haddington in the last few months, with a further  on the same estate due to be handed over by the end of this year.However, the local authority has revealed that despite the closure of construction sites for large parts of the year, it has continued to bring forward affordable housing.SInce September, the council has also taken ownership of seven new homes in Dunbar and  at Pinkie, Musselburgh.And during the year, six homes at Dovecot, Haddington, and  new homes at Limeylands, Ormiston, were handed over to East Lothian Housing Association for social rent.An additional  new extra-care council houses at Elder Street, Tranent, are due to be handed over to East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership.The latest handover of  homes at Letham Mains in Haddington, one of the largest new developments in East Lothian, includes two wheelchair-accessible homes.Justine Holmes, who got the keys to her new home at Letham Mains in September, is delighted and says the move has been le-changing for her and her two children.Justine, , said: ldquoWe have had a hard three years. I was made redundant and we lost our home as it was tied to my job. We spent a year in temporary accommodation and it was made even harder during lockdown as the property was really too small for our needs.ldquoWe are so happy with our forever home. We no longer feel we are living on top of each other and the kids love having their beautul garden ndash evenit is freezing.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesperson for housing, said: ldquoI was delighted to hear about the dference Justinersquos new home has made to her and her family.ldquoEast Lothian Councilrsquos programme of investment in social housing is essential in making a dference to iniduals and families who need high-quality, affordable accommodation.ldquoAs East Lothian is one of the fastest growing local authorities in Scotland, councillors agreed earlier this year to spend more than pound million over the next five years on building new council housing and modernising existing stock.ldquoWe will continue to work with developers and housing associations to stay on track with our plans to deliver the maximum number of council houses, homes for social rent via housing associations, and low-cost home ownership opportunities.Hart Builders was responsible for construction of the new council houses on the Letham Mains site.Gill Henry, business development director, said: ldquoHart Builders is delighted to have completed this first phase of development at Letham Mains and it is great to hear the residents are enjoyingtheir new homes.ldquoWe look forward to handing over the other  homes for more residents to settle in and enjoy in time for Christmas.ldquoThe final phases of this high-quality affordable housing development for East Lothian Council will be completed early in the new year.Meanwhile, Touchstone, part of Castle Rock Edin, has taken ownership of four three-bed homes for mid-market rent in Gullane.And in Cockenzie, six houses for veterans are expected to be handed over soon, with tenacies arranged through Veterans Housing Scotland.

title: christmas-tree-made-creels-created-dunbar-harbour
story: Ryan Stewart, Liam Brunton and Casey Brunton used more than  creels to create a unique version of a Christmas tree beneath Dunbar Castle.The display comes complete with lights and even a traditional orange and white lebuoy at the top in place of a star or angel.Ryan, , skipper of Ocean Crest, said: ldquoLiam just messaged me a few days ago with the idea.ldquoThey have done it other places through the west but I have never seen anything like it here.ldquoThe response has been quite good and Quentin Dimmer, the harbourmaster, says everybody has been happy with it.Between  and  creels were used to create the tree, which measures about five metres in height.Together, Liam, who fishes from Welcome Home, and Casey, who fishes near Aberdeen, along with Ryan and Quentin, spent four hours constructing the tree.Quentin felt that the display had really caught the eye of people visiting the harbour and praised the trio for their efforts.He said: ldquoThey are the up and coming younger generation of fishermen and, now with young children themselves, they wanted to bring a bit of festive cheer to Dunbar Harbour after what has been a dficult year for many people.ldquoAlmost straight away after it was completed, people were taking photos and the social media posts were very popular in the town and families were taking their children to see it.ldquoIt was so nice to see so many people smiling as they visited the harbour.

story: Tesco, ASDA, Aldi and Lidl are among the supermarkets to reveal they will be increasing trading hours to allow customers more time to shop and better enable social distancing practices ahead of Christmas day when families will be able to mix with up to three households.Online delivery slots and click and collect bookings are already in high demand as customers organise their festive food shopping in a bid to avoid any last minute rushes.Yet, in an effort to combat y queues in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, many grocers have looked at extending their opening hours to safely satisfy demand.So fear notyoursquore in need of an emergency trip to the shops!TescoMore than  Tesco stores are set to open their doors for  hours a day in the run up to Christmas, according to The Sun newspaper.The report says those Tesco stores will open around the clock from  December to Christmas Eve, with the rest of the chainrsquos stores operating from am to pm in the same period.With more than , stores, customers are encouraged to view what stores will be open and when using the supermarketrsquos online store locator HERE.All of Tescorsquos shops closed on Christmas Day last year and reopened on Boxing Day morning. title: new-coronavirus-symptom-discovered-experts
story: Up to now, symptoms have included a persistent cough, a high temperature and a loss of taste or smell.Now researchers in Spain claim to have found another symptom, they say a strange sensation in the nasal passage could be an early sign of coronavirus.% of patients studied by researchers in Barcelona have reported at least one nasal symptom ranging from excessive dryness to a continual sensation of having had a lsquonasal douche,rsquo BirminghamLive reports.Lead researcher, Jordi Naa said: ldquoThe presence of these nasal symptoms, and their early occurrence, could potentially facilitate early diagnosis of COVID- and initial social distancing efforts.ldquoIf you have any of the main symptoms of coronavirus, get a test as soon as possible, the NHS has said."If you have any of the main symptoms of coronavirus:  Get a test to checkyou have coronavirus as soon as possible.  You and anyone you live with should stay at home and not have visitors until you get your test result ndash only leave your home to have a test."Anyone in your support bubble should also stay at homeyou have been in close contact with them since your symptoms started or during the  hours before they started."

title: aldi-hiring-1-000-new-staff---apply
story: The budget supermarket chain is offering temporary contracts this Christmas as customers flock to the stores for their turkey and pigs in a blanket.Successful applicants from AldisChristmas recruitment drive will be supporting its permanent colleagues with tasks like replenishing stock and picking and packing orders made through the Deliveroo app.The , temporary Christmas roles come in addition to the , permanent jobs Aldi has created throughout . Currently, around , people work across the  stores in the UK.Kelly Stokes, Recruitment Director at Aldi UK, said, ldquoWe always need extra support over the busy Christmas period, but this year we need more people than ever before to help keep our shelves fully stocked for the festive season.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming new colleagues to the team, including those who jobs in retail may have been impacted by the pandemic.Store assistants at Aldi are paid a minimum hourly rate of pound. nationally, and pound. inside the M.To apply for a position at Aldi, yoursquoll need to head over to the recruitment website.There, you can see what kind of roles are available. Search for your area and browse through the jobs on offer.When you see one you want to apply to, you can click the apply button next to it. You might see that some jobs have a button that say ldquoregister instead. This means that there are no vacancies currently available at that location, but you can register your interest, meaning yoursquoll be alerted when a vacancy does appear.When you click apply, yoursquoll initially get a privacy notice that yoursquoll need to agree to first.Before starting the application process, yoursquoll need to fill out a form with your personal details, like your name, email address, phone number, home address and date of birth.Next, yoursquoll answer some role-specic questions and,successful, yoursquoll be able to complete the Aldi SmartStyles Test. The test presents you with a number of statements that you are asked to rate as most to least like you.Should you pass this stage, yoursquoll then move onto the Situational Judgement Test, which involves choosing the most appropriate and inappropriate solutions to some work situations that you may find yourself in.Aldi states that the application process should take around  to  minutes in total.

title: covid-scotland-scotrail-offers-students-50-per-cent-discount-get-home-christmas
story: A mass testing programme of students planning to head home over the festive period is currently under way, in a bid to limit risk of transmission and provide reassurance to those travelling home to their families and loved ones.And now students will only need to pay half price for travel, on any ScotRail service until December .The train operator run by Dutch firm Abellio hopes the move will help students worried about getting home to their families under the current coronavirus travel restrictions.Students will first need to record a negative Covid- test before travelling, which could make it dficult to book specic train services due to testing appointments and the time spent awaiting results.Herersquos a little Christmas cheer for all of Scotlandrsquos university students. Get home for Christmas with % off an Off-Peak Return ticket. No need to pre-book your ticket either. https:t.co DVyuTAaNsHowever ScotRail is offering a flexible, open- ticket which will remain valid for one month after purchase in a bid to allow most students toto their studies in January after another negative coronavirus test with minimal hassle.All a student needs to do is turn up at a staffed ticket office with their ID, jump on board and head home to their loved ones.Students will be able to purchase the discounted tickets up until  December, which would mean they would have until  January to use theportion of the journey.Lesley Kane, ScotRail Commercial Director, said: ldquoStudents are going through a hard enough time just now trying to keep up with their studies while worrying about catching coronavirus and balancing their finances.ldquoWe think this half price deal on tickets is the best gt we can give them before Christmas and wersquore sure it will be very popular amongst students who want to get home to see loved ones at this special family time of the year.ldquoWe are confident ScotRail will be able to carry all passengers safely over the festive period by observing the five rules for safer travel, including wearing a face covering and maintaining physical distancing.The Scottish Government is currently working with universities across the country and the UK Governmentrsquos testing programme to offer free lateral flow testing, which can provide results in  minutes.However, a ldquosurge in travel is expected over the five-day Christmas period as families form their festive bubbles with loved ones.And it is feared that the temporary easing of coronavirus restrictions, which will allow three households to mix in a bubble from December  to , will lead to trains, roads and coaches being busier as many people look to make the most of the opportunity to spend Christmas with family and friends.Coach operator National Express said it is increasing its services to meet demand in the run-up to Christmas.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion has said it expects a ldquosurge in passengers over the five days.General secretary Mick Cash said: ldquoRMT supports the railway in playing its role in ensuring that people can see their loved ones this Christmas and I will be seeking urgent discussions with all the train companies and Government to ensure that this is carefully and properly planned to protect the safety of both workers and passengers.lrmHowever, Rail industry body the Rail Delivery Groupsaid that there is ldquono concern of overcrowding on train carriages, while thousands of services are expected to run daily to cope with more passengers.And the AA has said it was not ldquooverly concerned that traffic congestion could occur on roads, suggesting many families had cancelled plans to spend Christmas together.Edmund King, AA president, said: ldquoTwo fths of drivers who had already cancelled festive travel plans may have been wary of risk to their loved ones ndash or perhaps secretly happy to avoid a visit to the in-laws.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-reports-positive-case-coronavirus

title: covid-19-asymptomatic-testing-site-opens-queen-margaret-university
story: Funded by the UK Government, the testing site ndash for people showing no symptoms of coronavirus ndash is running in partnership with the university, Scottish Government and NHS Test and Protect to help students move home for the winter break and protect the wider community.It is hoped that testing ndash as well as limiting social mixing for two weeks before students go home ndash will help break the chain of transmission amongst students, especially when they are infected but are not aware of it, and help ensure the safety of their loved ones.The ATS will conduct lateral flow tests ndash rapid turnaround tests that can process samples on site without the need for laboratory equipment.The university is working with NHS Test  Protect to set up the on-campus ATS so that students who intend to move household over the winter break and are without symptoms, are able to get tested and asked to self-isolatethey test positive, or be quickly reassuredthey do not.Sir Paul Grice, the universityrsquos principal, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to offer this facility.ldquoWhile many of our students will remain in Edinburgh and East Lothian, we know that many others are planning to change household or to visit family and friends over the winter break.ldquoBy participating in testing, they will help avoid the spread of Covid to their family, friends and the wider community.Testing is available for all students. Visit qmu.ac.uk coronavirus

title: hayley-cohen-become-east-lothians-youngest-church-minister
story: The Rev Cohen ndash the countyrsquos youngest minister and the seventh youngest in Scotland ndash is due to be ordained and inducted at Northesk Parish Church, Musselburgh, this evening .Originally from New Jersey in the USA, she is looking forward to her first charge after falling in love with Scotland as a student.She succeeds the Rev Alison MacDonald, who is now minister at St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington.Ms Cohen ndash who describes herself as ldquopretty outgoing and extroverted ndash first came to Scotland as a study-abroad student in  at the University of Edinburgh.She said: ldquoI quickly fell in love with Scotland and knew that I wanted toas soon as I could when my year at Edinburgh was over.ldquoDuring that year, I met my now husband, Ross , while we were both studying theology at New College. Ross is originally from outside Lancaster, England.ldquoI ed to Scotland in  after completing my BA in the US to spend a year working for Balerno Parish Church as their parish assistant. This was a fantastic year and really gave me a taste of the le of the parish minister in Scotland.She ed to the US in  and studied for her Masters of Divinity at Princeton Theological Seminary, and began training for ministry in the Presbyterian Church .After graduating with her Masters in , she went to work in Jerusalem for an ecumenical institute that ran educational pilgrimages and sabbatical programmes.She married Ross in Edinburgh and the couple moved to Durham, where Ross was working towards his PhD, and Ms Cohen applied to transfer into the Church of Scotland.She said: ldquoThis decision to transfer was an easy one for me to make given my love of Scotland, my experience working in a Church of Scotland parish through my time in Balerno and the long-standing relationship between the Presbyterian Churchand Church of Scotland.ldquoMy transfer was accepted and I went on placement at St Andrewrsquos Clermiston in Edinburgh under the supervision of the Rev Alistair Keil, who Irsquom delighted will be preaching at my ordination. I was with St Andrewrsquos until October.ldquoI was approved to begin applying for my first charge just as the UK was entering lockdown in March.ldquoIt was clear there wasnrsquot going to be anything normal about the process of looking for a church.ldquoBut Northesk was actually the first parish profile on the Church of Scotland website at which I looked.ldquoI was moved by their expression of care for their ministers. Northesk has had five ministers in the last  years I will be the sixth. To me, this is an indicator that ministers are made to feel very much welcome and at home in Northesk.ldquoWhen I began to meet members of the congregation through interviews, first online and then in person, it was clear they were incredibly friendly and welcoming people willing to get stuck in and do the work that needs doing for love of God, their church, and their community.She added: ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to becoming the minister of Northesk and I am particularly excited to meet the people of Fisherrow and Musselburgh, whether they are churchgoers or not.ldquoIrsquom from the US, so Irsquom pretty outgoing and extroverted. I like listening to people and hearing their stories. If anyone sees me in the street, please stop me, introduce yourself, and say hello. Irsquod be delighted to meet you.ldquoMy plans for the church will be made in conversation with the congregation after spending time with them and listening to where they have been, where they are now, and where they want to go. We know there is a lot of work to do but I am personally very excited for the possibilities that are before us.ldquoRight now, wersquore looking forward to the season of Advent and Christmas. I know things will feel very dferent this year at Christmas because of the pandemic but Irsquom hoping that Northesk can continue to be a place where people can come and celebrate joy and the hope of the birth of Jesus, whether at home or in person.In her free time, Ms Cohen enjoys bird-watching and is delighted to be so close to Levenhall Links.She said: ldquoI enjoy walking with my husband. We love exploring new places together.ldquoIrsquom a keen home cook, singer, painter, yoga practitioner and an all-round nature lover.Northesk sold the old manse on New Street and the couple live in the new manse near Pinkie.Simon Fairnie, on behalf of Northesk Church, said: ldquoThe congregation are delighted at the appointment of, and welcome, their new, young minister. She will be a lsquofresh startrsquo for Northesk Church and its parish.

title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-gets-engaged-danielle-murphy
story: The undefeated star got down on one knee in front of his long-time girlfriend Danielle Murphy yesterdaywhile on a luxury yacht in Dubai.Danielle took to social media this morningto say: ldquo  , the day I said YES.ldquoOne of the best days of my le, Josh pulled out all the stops and I couldnrsquot have asked for a better day!ldquoThank you to everyone for the well wishes and love, Irsquom totally overwhelmed!ldquoItrsquos times like this that I wish heaven had a phone so I could phone big Jimmy [her late father] to tell him my best friend has made me the happiest girl on the planet.Josh, originally from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, is the current holder of the WBA and IBF World Super Lightweight titles.The -year-old is expected to step into the ring with Jose Carlos Ramirez, who holds the WBC and WBO World Super Lightweight titles, in the spring for a unication bout.Josh also previously took gold at the Commonwealth Games in Glasgow in  before turning pro.He also posted on social media, saying: ldquoSo she just said yes.ldquoI finally plucked up the courage to ask my beautul girlfriend to be my we. Not before time though.Among those offering congratulations were his trainer Ben Davison, former world heavyweight champion David Haye and Joshrsquos former opponent Regis Prograis.

title: morham-man-rory-gammell-launches-new-wee-smoky-whisky
story: Rory Gammell, whose father Patrick also served as chairman of the Lamp of Lothian Trust, said he began to develop the concept for a whisky ldquothat is inclusive and welcoming to a younger audience and non-experts while living in San Francisco.The result was Wee Smoky, whose first limited-edition batch of  bottles sold out within four days of being launched on November .Rory said: ldquoCocktail culture was growing and I noticed that people werenrsquot choosing to mix Scotch whisky.ldquoI felt it was mostly because it looked too old fashioned to attract younger drinkers. It wasnrsquot inviting people to mix it.ldquoUpon trying a cocktail made with a smoky Scotch whisky, I had a lsquoEurekarsquo moment.Rory, , grew up in Morham, near Haddington, and attended The Compass School.In , he took part in the lsquo Hours of LeMonsrsquo endurance race for old bangers, on the Sonoma Raceway in Calornia, along with friends Sam Smith, John Austin and Wolfgang Muller.They raced in a  Mazda MX- named Nessie ndash complete with a Saltire across the bonnet and a giant lsquoSee You Jimmy Hatrsquo.After eight years working abroad, he came home via the Saltire Fellowship to work for Edrington, the maker of The Macallan.Rory, who now lives in Edinburgh, said: ldquoHaving worked in both the US and Hong Kong, I understand the strength of the Scottish brand worldwide.ldquoThat experience has played a huge part in developing a whisky that can celebrate a more playful side of Scotland.Wee Smoky, described as smooth, fruity and lightly smoky, is Roryrsquos solo venture, distilled in Edinburgh and bottled in distinctive electric blue and pink bottles.It will see its next batch, set for wide distribution, released some time next year.To find out more about the whisky, go to www.weesmoky

title: athelstaneford-youngsters-fly-saltire-bbc-st-andrews-day
story: Pupils at Athelstaneford Primary School appeared on BBC TVrsquos Reporting Scotland, parading the flag, which measured about  metres by  metres, before it was hoisted on the school flagpole, where it will remain for the next year.The ceremony was devised by Stewart Brown, headteacher at the school, with pupils told the story of the Saltire and St Andrew and its connection to the village.Each year, the school is presented with a new Saltire by the Scottish Flag Trust, which runs the visitor centre behind the village church and the Saltire Memorial, which commemorates the battle in AD. Legend tells that a vision of a St Andrewrsquos cross against the blue sky spurred an army of Scots and Picts on to victory over an army of Angles.On St Andrewrsquos Day, the Trust launched a new website saltire.scot as part of a local and international appeal to raise pound, to restore and renew this important historic site. Dave Williamson, Trust convener, said the ceremony went very well and praised the youngsters for their enthusiasm.He also revealed a last minute hitch meant the flag raising almost had to be called off when the flagpole developed a problem at the top some -feet off the ground.He said: ldquoWe made a Facebook appeal for help and local farmer and former school former pupil Craig Thomson came to the rescue with his friend Brian Paxton and used a giant cherry picker to fix the pole within half an hour of the appeal being made.ldquoA great day for all.

title: gardening-create-showstopping-christmas-flower-display
story: Gardening: How to create a showstopping Christmas flower displayA finished festive bouquet of flowersFestive flowers are a must in the run-up to Christmas, but how can you make the most of what you have in your own garden to add interest to a rich display A iety of foliage and berries foraged from your own plot can add a seasonal accent to Christmas flowers, says Vicky Wilson, product design manager at Interflora."With just a few winter blooms and some foraged foliage, its easier than youd think to transform your hallway, living room or anywhere  thats in need of a few good tidings this season," she says.She offers the following step-by-step for a showstopping Christmas floral display.... What youll need red roses red skimmia pink snowberry red spray rosesScots pine clippings eucalyptus salal tips Usually the pine, eucalyptus, skimmia and snowberries can be foraged from a garden, but you might need to call on your local florist for the roses, which will be the signature blooms.Lay all the stems out on a table youd like to use and prepare the stems by removing any leaves and thorns on the bottom half.Where to startTake a foliage stem in your hand, holding the stem roughly halfway up, and one of your focal flowers. This is the start of your arrangement.As you pick up and add more stems, hold each at a slight angle, so your bouquet starts to build in a natural way.Make it evenAlternate your flowers and leaves, adding a flower stem and a foliage stem, turning the bouquet each time you add one.Make flowers the showstopperMake sure the flower heads are positioned slightly above the foliage, so they really show themselves off.For a really stunning arrangement, add flowers in a triangular pattern. It might sound strange, but this means each flower type is evenly distributed through the whole bouquet.Secure the bouquetOnce youve added all the flowers and foliage, tie the bouquet exactly where youve been holding the stems.Once you have secured the bouquet with string, cut each stem at a slight angle using a pair of sharp scissors or secateurs. Hold the bouquet up to the vase to help you determine how much of the stems you need to chop off.Fill a clean vase with water and pop your bouquet in. You may want to tweak it slightlythere are any wayward stems or foliage that arent quite in the right place, before finding the perfect spot to show off your efforts.For more information visit interflora.

title: gardening-give-houseplants-festive-makeover
story: Gardening: How to give your houseplants a festive makeoverGet into the festive spirit with your indoor plantsLooking at ways to throw your houseplants into the spotlight this festive season  Perhaps you havent got room for a tree and want to make an alternative statement, or maybe you just want to give your plants a chance to shine."You can quickly transform your existing plants to make them feel part of the celebrations," says Rebecca Stanton, stylist at Dobbies Garden Centres , which has seen a rising demand for new ieties of houseplants.Whether youre part of the growing urban jungle club or have just a few statement plants on display, its easy to give them a merry makeover by adding fairy lights, simple decorations or just repositioning them, says Stanton.Here, she shares her top tips to give your houseplants a stylish festive twist.. Regroup your greensA quick and easy way to make a dramatic display is to gather up houseplants that might usually live in separate rooms of your house and group them together, either in the middle of the dining table or on a hallway side table.Rather than repotting the plants, buy pots which will fit the plant with its existing pot, meaning that when its time to take down the decorations you can simply pop them out andthem to their usual home.. Add some sparkleTwinkling fairy lights instantly add magic and they are the ideal way to bring some sparkle to houseplants. Drape lights around branches and foliage as you would do with your traditional tree, making sure that the set is suitable for your plant.Avoid anything too heavy that the plant wont be able to comfortably hold the weight of. Choose battery-operated fairy lights so you dont have to worry about placing plants near a power source - the battery pack is easy enough to subtly hide below the top of the pot.If you are looking for an alternative tree with eco credentials that wont take up too much room, the Araucarialooks like a mini tree. Unlike the cut iety though, you can keep it all year round as it can go outside through the summer months then brought back in each Christmas.. Wrap it upWrapping paper doesnt need to be saved for concealing gts. Instead, use it to dress your plants and their pots, rather like giving your houseplants Christmas jumpers! Create a cone-like shape around your houseplant to give it a speedy transformation - simple, sleek and stylish, its cost-effective too.. Frame your plantAs well as adding decorations to existing houseplants, you can frame plants to give them a festive look. A wire frame planted over a miniature Christmas tree with added lights will add a Scandinavian vibe. Choose one which is small enough to be easily portable, so you can use it to bring festive cheer to ious parts of your home, from the dining table to your home office desk.. Add festive accessories to terrariumsSelf contained and mess-free, terrariums can be easily updated so they become part of your festive decor. Wrap a ribbon around bottle-shaped containers, pop in a few mini baubles or add a lightweight set of warm white micro lights within the glass dome.The trick is to not over-complicate, as terrariums look best styled more simply to avoid detracting too much from the plants on display inside.. Keep it greenOne of the easiest ways to lt a room is the addition of some greenery. Consider a large plant such as Fiddle-leaf figwhich can grow to more than ft and is sure to make a statement. An all year-round star of the show, it might even be an alternative Christmas tree of choice for unconventional decorators.Mix up plants of dferent sizes, from cheese plantsand overhead hanging plants like Curly Spider, or String of Pearls. For an organic look, accessorise plants with natural colours and materials like wood and rattan. To go the extra green mile, frame windows with a garland of fresh foliage and string lights. A celebration of all things green, your living space will feel like a cosy indoor garden oasis.

title: agenda-helping-art-community-help
story: ESTABLISHED in March by my former art lecturer, artist Matthew Burrows MBE to help artists struggling due to Covid-, in April Artist Support Pledgeannounced that pound million sales had been generated via a new economic model revealing a new ldquogted and egalitarian micro economyrsquo.It has since become a global movement of connected communities committed to an equitable and sustainable economy for artist and makers of all countries, media and ethnicities.The project uses social media  Instagram for artists to post images using #artistsupportpledge giving details of their works and price . If people are interested in buying, they message the artist. Anyone can buy the work and artists donrsquot need permission to join.Each time an artist reaches pound, of sales, they pledge to buy pound of work from other artists. There are no enforcements. It is a system based on trust where everyone at every level can contribute in supporting artists and makers.I have been an active participant and supporter of ASP since its formation and can testy that it has indeed helped me continue to work as an artist throughout this pandemic by selling and buying art works via #artistsupportpledge.I share ASPrsquos commitment to sustainability, a belief that underpins many of the works I have produced throughout the course of this year, which were inspired by and redeploy Boris Johnsonrsquos letter to the nation.Sent in April to all households across Britain to urge them to heed the Governmentrsquos coronavirus guidance and stay home wherever possible, the letter was delivered to  million homes, reaching all  million residents in Britain as part of the Governmentrsquos public information campaign at a cost of pound. million.For me, these letters highlighted the incompetence of the Government in its handling of the pandemic. This was important to me because it is about taking a stance against the Government and Chancellor ishi Sunakrsquos statement about the need for artists to retrain.That statement highlighted the hypocrisy of the Government. These letters cost almost poundm and were a waste of taxpayersrsquo money because most people chucked them straight in the bin the information was already available online and no account was made for the visually impaired. My artworks recycle and repurpose these letters and, by so doing, make a comment on the need for sustainability.Last year the art industry was worth pound billion in the UK, yet the average artist earned less than poundk. Many of the artists who struggle to survive make a considerable contribution to our erse cultural landscape.ASP does not believe it is acceptable for artists to go hungry and live a le of debt and worry to make such a valued contribution. Instead, it believes, as I do, that all artists who make that contribution to our common good should be appropriately supported.ASP believes that an equitable and sustainable future economically and environmentally must begin by examining the cultural values we live by that artists are central to this debate and that all artists are important in maintaining the permaculture that is our global artistic ecosystem.Its vision is for a sustainable economy and supportive community for all artists and makers, in all countries and in all medias and traditions. It is a vision which I support fully.

title: Rosemary Goring  Mower is less when it comes to making your garden bloom
story: DEATH to the lawnmower, dump the leaf blower, ditch the power hose. Such is the controversial message from Francesca Osowska, the chief executive of NatureScot, formerly known as Scottish Natural Heritage. In some quarters shersquoll be preaching to the converted. Gardeners whose summers are ruined by weekly or fortnightly grass cutting, who would rather spend their time dead-heading roses or sipping Pimms on the patio, will surely leap at the idea.Osowskarsquos plea is not for gardens to be left to run wild, but for those of us with a bit of lawn to set aside an area to sprout, untouched by the mower. In these corners, weeds and wildflowers, and the insects, birds and other creatures that live off them will flourish.But her vision is for wilderness or wildness to be embraced more broadly than by devotees of the Beechgrove Garden. If redesigned, urban areas, which contain swathes of parkland as well as private gardens, could also help rewild the country. If parks were kept less like Centre Court at Wimbledon and more like a stretch of meadow or marsh you might find in the heart of the countryside, towns and cities could soon be alive with the sound of birdsong and bees.Osowskarsquos ambition is to spark a radical sht ndash you might call it a renaissance ndash in the way we see parks and gardens. Changing our perspective, she hopes, will not only help wildle but signicantly benefit humankind too. She believes the Covid  crisis, for instance, can be directly linked to the shrinking acreage allowed for nature. As she explains: ldquoThe increasing intensity of livestock farming, deforestation, crop monocultures, globalisation and large urban environments all make viral transference more likely and rapid once viruses enter human populations. Give more room to the wild, she suggests, and as balance is restored, the risk of viruses crossing barriers from animal to human, as in the recent case of Danish mink farms, will be reduced.Whatever the science of pandemics, and the validity of Osowskarsquos conclusions, for most of us the idea of letting things run amok at the bottom of the garden already makes sense. We donrsquot need the carrot or stick incentive of warding against another global pandemic to commit to a bit of scrubland. In fact, the wilding memo has been in circulation among gardeners for decades. Many were fighting a rearguard action against climate change and loss of bioersity long before it became fashionable. This silent army, in fleeces and wellington boots, has been largely unsung, but the rewards have been rich. The abundance of flora and fauna that populated their gardens turned them into a communal space in the widest sense.Reshaping our ideas of civic parks might be a bigger challenge. Irsquove always found immaculate flowerbeds and bowling green grass faintly depressing, a pale imitation of the countryside and its teeming fields and woods. A pale imitation, indeed, of my own garden, where unkemptness has been elevated to an art form. Yet for some, the word park is synonymous with symmetry and order, with every begonia in its place, like an immaculate table setting, and the lawns to be admired but not trodden.Even so, Irsquod say Osowska is pressing on an open door. Formality, in almost every sphere of le, is becoming a thing of the past. The days of parkies yelling at those who stepped off the path now seem almost comical. Most of us, I am sure, would prefer a more casual landscape, less geometrical, more random. How much more relaxing to take a stroll in a place where grasses and bushes sway in the wind, shrubberies are tangled and dense, and the sound of birdsong and of children running through the long grass drowns out the strimmer or chainsaw.Itrsquos amazing how swtly new ideas about outdoor space take hold. A century ago, most peoplersquos gardens were more like allotments, primarily for growing fruit and veg, with flowers and shrubs a decorative indulgence. Lawn for leisure or aesthetic pleasure was a luxury. When the mood changed, and gardens became an outdoor room, the lettuce bed and potato drills were banished. Now, as the pendulum swings back to a point somewhere between the two, awareness about giving nature more space is catching on. Butthe prospect of untamed grass and weeds dismays you, there are countless other ways of nurturing nature.When it comes to green spaces, the climate emergency has opened peoplersquos eyes to the importance of creative mess, of not sweeping and tidying every inch asit were our kitchen, but allowing it to breathe. Something as simple as a heap of undisturbed leaves, a bundle of sticks or wall of logs, allows hedgehogs and other mammals to survive the winter. Rotting foliage and flowers run to seed are a breakfast buffet for birds and insects, who in turn are prey for other hungry wildle. In spring and summer, therersquos nothing richer for flying insects than nettles which, being so quick to replenish themselves, are also good for soup. Or so neighbours tell me.But in case you are about to throw away the key to the garden shed, this is not an excuse for letting nature take over. Some husbandry is essential, to ensure plants and trees thrive to the best of their abilities, and are not overpowered by the thugs of the undergrowth.So the lawnmower is by no means the greatest threat to our future. Itrsquos not something I can get rid of, since we donrsquot own one. Butwe did not have the grass trimmed throughout the summer by a roving gardener whose machine is tough enough to cut a path through heather, it would be thigh-high by the start of June. Green-fingered friends who regularly trim their grass use the cuttings for compost, thereby improving the soil. In other words, all grass is good. And no matter how you let yours grow, whether it is buzzcut or left to its own devices, it is infinitely better than covering the ground in concrete or stone. Soon we will look back on gardens turned into car parks with disbelief. How could we suffocate the land like this  In the meantime, long may your weeds and wallflowers grow .

story: THE world has become a playground for the pals of David Attenborough, with wild otters spotted strolling in Edinburgh city centre. Gangs of foxes are also making inroads into Glasgow, loitering in George Square like a gaggle of Goths enjoying a mass grump.Reader Ian Fenn isnrsquot particularly outraged by this impish imposition on human territory.ldquoAs long as they donrsquot start attending the theatre, making small talk in restaurants, watching live football matches and hugging elderly relatives, he adds.Taste testA RECENT Diary story about a lollipop lady reminds Megan Harradine from Crossmyloof of the elderly chap who used to help her and her school friends cross busy roads many years ago.A quirky bloke, he once muttered: ldquoDinnae call me a lollipop man, cos this isnae really a lollipop.He then took a lusty lick of his STOP sign, then added: ldquoSee  Tastes awfy.Festive ferocityAS we dig deeper into December many people are opening Advent calendars. story: The Daily MailJanet Street-Porter said the pound, handout to lsquowetrsquo pubs - the ones that donrsquot serve food - to help them survive lockdown was hardly worth the effort.ldquo Boris claimed that the British pub was lsquoat the heart of our communitiesrsquo - butthat was the case, why were so many closing long before Covid arrived on our shores , she asked. ldquoIn  almost  pubs shut - at least two every single day of the year. The number of small pubs - employing less than ten people, has halved since .She said society had changed and, with dozens of channels available at home and cheap supermarket alcohol, people had simply stopped going to pubs.ldquoBoris was right when he said that pubs and restaurants lsquohave born the bruntrsquo of the economic crisis caused by Covi, she said. ldquoBut his lack of a coherent and simple strategy is responsible for their current woes.She said that even when pubs can reopen, they might have to demand that customers have been vaccinated.ldquoThe Minister in charge of overseeing the rollout of the new vaccines has dropped a heavy hint that although take-up of the jab will be a matter of personal choice, hospitality, entertainment and sports venues could insist that patrons show an lsquoimmunity passportrsquo to gain entry, she said.ldquoButthat sends some of the worst pubs to the wall, is that the end of the world  I note therersquos been no stream of angry women moaning about the demise of the wet pub. And I certainly wonrsquot shed any tears over them.Devi Sridhar, chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh, said she was repeatedly asked what families should do over Christmas.ldquoIrsquom torn between giving people the emotionally reassuring and comforting answer they want to hear or sticking bluntly to the best scientic evidence we have about transmission and suppression, she said. ldquoThe truth is the virus that causes Covid- does not care that it is Christmas or New Yearrsquos Eve. It rapidly spreads indoors and in poorly ventilated settings, particularly in households, when people gather together.She said sitting two meters apart and disinfecting surfaces wasnrsquot going to stop transmission.The only truly safe way to spend time with relatives, she said, was to self isolate for two weeks ahead of meeting up. With the virus taking  days to incubate, a negative test today might not show negative tomorrow, or next week, she added.ldquoWhile we all clapped for months for the NHS staff, we should keep them in the forefront of our minds this winter, she said. ldquoNHS doctors, nurses, support staff and cleaners have to show up each day to work in hospitals and GP practices and deal with whatever is thrown at them.ldquoWe all need to play our part in keeping the burden off health services. This might mean postponing group gatherings until the spring or summer next year, and doing our best now to avoid getting the virus and passing it on to others.The The newspaperrsquos leader column reflected on the Health Secretaryrsquos news that his step-grandfather had died of coronavirus when he spoke on Tuesday night.ldquoIn my family, as in so many others, wersquove lost a loving husband, a father, a grandfather to this awful disease, Matt Hancock said. ldquoSo from the bottom of my heart, I want to say thank you to everyone in Liverpool for getting this awful virus under control.The column said he described  as a ldquoshocker but confirmed members of the public would receive the vaccine ldquofrom next weekldquoThe Government said the approval of the vaccine follows ldquomonths of rigorous clinical trials which found it met its standards of safety, quality and effectiveness, it said.ldquoEngland finishes the second national lockdown today and s to the regional tiered system of restrictions.ldquoMr Hancock tweeted on news of the vaccine: ldquoHelp is on its way. ldquoThe MHRA has formally authorised the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine for Covid-.ldquoThe NHS stands ready to start vaccinating early next week.ldquoThe UK is the first country in the world to have a clinically approved vaccine for supply.

title: covid-lockdown-church-scotland-minister-calls-nationwide-doorstep-carol-service
story: Rev Mike Goss is urging households to gather in front of their homes for Doorstep Carols - which will mean for a not-so-silent nighton December , when Scots break into song at pm.With Covid- restrictions curtailing traditional door-to-door singing, he appealed for the streets to be filled with classics like Away in a Manger and O Come, All Ye Faithful to send out a strong message that Christmas is ldquonot cancelled.:Jason Leitch defends Christmas guidance insisting Scotland is innovative enough to manageThe minister of Barry Parish Church and Carnoustie Church in Angus said: ldquoPeople are understandably feeling gloomy because the impact of restrictions will almost certainly mean that Christmas will look dferent this year.ldquoBut the true meaning is still the same and I hope that family groups and people in bubbles coming out on to their doorsteps, ensuring they are standing two metres away from their neighbours, will provide a sense of joy, peace and comfort.He added: ldquoIt is fair to say that a lot of people feel that they have lost their singing voices this year because we have been unable to sing in church since March and many choirs are finding putting on online events challenging.ldquoDoorstep Carols is an opportunity for people to come together in small numbers in a socially distanced and responsible way as part of a wider community across Scotland and celebrate this special time of year.Mr Goss also urged churches to record short videos of their membersrsquo doorstep carol singing and post them on social media.Members of Kirk congregations across Angus have said they will take part in what could become the largest Christmas Carol concert held in Scotland.How can I get involved The event will take place on December  at pm, and is to feature five carols and will last approximately  minutes.Words to the five carols can be downloaded from Mr Gossrsquo church websites ahead of the concert.

story: John Swinney made the comments while giving evidence to Holyroods Covid- Committee.Discussions had been taking place over potentially extending the holidays due to the coronavirus pandemic.:Anger as Christmas school holidays in Scotland are not extendedA leaked document suggested the breakcould run from December  to January .Holiday arrangements y across Scotland, with most schools ingbetween January  and .Mr Swinney said: "Being in school is in the best interests of children and our priority remains to ensure schools are safe, and open."I want to thank school leaders, teachers and school staff for their outstanding commitment to education that has enabled children and young people to learn safely in school since August.:Nicola Sturgeon thinking intensely about axing exams in  and hints at decision soon"The advice I have received from public health officials, and the Covid- sub-group on education and childrenrsquos issues, is not to alter Christmas and New Year holiday dates."We also know vulnerable children may be at greater riskthey are out of school for an extended period, and I am mindful of the impact an extension to school holidays would have for working parents."For these reasons I do not see a clear rationale for changing term dates and disrupting childrenrsquos education."

title: issue-day-moment-alone-mona-lisa
story: How so The chance to see Leonardo da Vincirsquos masterpiece is one of a raft of ldquoonce-in-a-letime experiences that have gone up for auction this week. The successful bidder will attend the annual examination of the Mona Lisa, which sees the artwork taken out of its case at the Louvre in Paris for inspection.Its a ldquohot ticket Seeing the painting usually involves battling crowds taking pictures on cameras and smartphones just to get a glimpse, so this offer ldquoto be able to look straight into the eyes of the Mona Lisa and admire this iconic work from up close, is proving to be a huge draw.The allure of the painting endures Painted sometime between  and , it is known to be one of Da Vincirsquos favourites. The identity of the woman has long been debated, but it is thought to be Lisa Gherardini, the we of a Florentine silk merchant, whose husband commissioned the work.However A less likely theory is that the painting was in fact a self-portrait, with analysts noting similarities between it and a later self-portrait of Da Vinci. No matter, the questions over the subjectrsquos identity - and her mysterious half-smile - have combined to make the Mona Lisa an object of lingering fascination.Itrsquos got a crack Experts remain concerned about a crack located at the top of the wooden  the work is painted on, which has been there since at least the th century. And so, each year, the painting is taken down from the wall out of its glass case ldquofor a fleeting moment of examination.It was once stolen In , a former Louvre employee, believing the painting belonged in his Italian homeland, walked out of the gallery with the painting underneath his painterrsquos smock. He was caught two years later and the artwork safely ed.When does the auction end Christiersquos France, which is organising the online auction, expect the experience to sell for up to pound, when the hammer comes down on December  - the current highest bid is around pound. Proceeds will be used to help offset losses due to the pandemicrsquos impact. Jean-Luc Martinez, president and director of the Louvre, said plans include the Louvre Museum Studio, a new space that will focus on artistic education. He added: This period of pandemic, which is hitting the most vulnerable in society first, makes this project even more necessary.Other auction items include Other experiences include a private tour of the museum with Martinez a torchlight night tour of the museum and a private concert in the Caryatids Hall on the ground floor. Winning bidders will have a two-year window in which to witness the restoration.

title: covid-immunity-passports-practical-ethical-flaws-nicola-sturgeon-said
story: The First Minister said there were issues with data security and Covid safety around using paperwork or phone apps as proof of having been vaccinated.ldquoWe have no plans to introduce immunity passports, she insisted at FMQs, following mixed messages at the top of the UK Government.Earlier this week, the new UK vaccines minister Nadhim Zahawi told the BBC the government was ldquolooking at the technology for immunity passports.He said: ldquoI think youll probably find that restaurants and bars and cinemas and other venues, sports venues, will probably also use that system - as they have done with the app.ldquoI think that in many ways the pressure will come from both ways, from service providers wholl say, Look, demonstrate to us that you have been vaccinated.ldquoWe will make the technology as easy and accessible as possible.Baroness Harding, head of NHS Test and Trace in England, also revealed her staff were researching how to combine test results and vaccine status in the official Covid app.She said the goal was ldquoin the future to be able to have a single record as a citizen of your test results and whether yoursquove been vaccinated.But the issue sparked privacy and civil liberties concerns, with campaign groups and ious politicians opposing any such identication system.Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove then downplayed the idea on Wednesday, saying people would not be required to carry identication to prove they have been vaccinated against coronavirus to go to theatres, stadiums or hospitality venues.At FMQs, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said he was ldquonervous about talk of immunity passports.He said: ldquoPutting personal information on to large databases has risks to privacy and the possibility of fraud hacking and theft.ldquoThe World Health Organization questions the value of immunity passports, and the UK Government has said that it has no plans to introduce them.ldquoI want to go further, and I think that we need guidance.ldquoWe might need to make changes to the law to protect people from its misuse. What is the Scottish Governmentrsquos policy on immunity passports Ms Sturgeon said she shared some of Mr Renniersquos ldquophilosophical and ethical objections, and added there were also ldquopractical issues.She said: ldquoItrsquos not something we plan to do, itrsquos not something we favour.ldquoWe know from trials that the Pfizer vaccine suppresses illness but we will not know for some time, once the vaccine is in use, whether vaccination prevents onward transmission.ldquoFrom a practical point of view, it is flawed to say that, just because someone has had the vaccine, they cannot pass Covid on to somebody .ldquoWe have no plans to introduce immunity passports, just as we have no plans to make vaccination compulsory, although we will strongly encourage maximum take-up of the vaccine.ldquoWe will always consider whether legal changes are necessary to support our policy position, but the starting point is to make it clear that immunity passports are not something that this Parliament is contemplating.

title: new-elizabethans-andrew-marr-series-one-episode-one-review
story: BBC iPlayer***WATCHING popular history can be a perilous game. The viewer has to keep an eye out for a gimmick-hungry presenter who might suddenly appear in fancy dress , or lurch into creeping Jesus mode .No such worries during New Elizabethans with Andrew Marr. Or so you might have thought.There he was at the despatch box in the Commons, telling us about Churchill addressing the house on the death of George VI. The PMs voice rang out in audio.Good old Andy. Class act. You can rely on him not to do anything so cheesy as a Churchill impersonation. And then he did. It was a cautionary reminder that no presenter can resist hamming it up given half a chance.Marrrsquos central idea, to be set out over three episodes, was that the ascent to the throne of Queen Elizabeth in  ushered in an era of huge change that led to the UK as we know it today. The transformation was led by iniduals he called ldquochange-makers or ldquonew Elizabethans.The first episode, shown last night, was titled ldquoBuilding a new Society. Step forward Jan Morris, Nancy Mitford, Diana Dors, Ruth Ellis and others. Marr promised to avoid the usual suspects in favour of ldquocurious and creative characters and for the most part he made good on that.But there were still some disappointingly obvious selections, such as Mary Whitehouse , and there was no-one to alarm even the most skittish of horses.A swaggering Weegie in the shape of Alan McGee was as rock and roll as the first episode could muster.McGee left school at  with one Orsquolevel, Marr told us. But like others during the Thatcher years he knew a good deal in the Enterprise Allowance when he saw it. Under this scheme the Government paid pound a week to anyone starting their own business.McGee used the money to found Creation Records.ldquoFor me, said Marr, ldquoAlan McGee is a true Elizabethan, both a product of the time and a powerful influence on the age. [He] tells us a lot about the shts to class and opportunity that were happening in Scotland and much of the rest of Britain during the s.The son of a mechanic and a shop worker, McGee came of working age when the old industries were gone and the new, service and leisure sectors were starting to boom.ldquoBy his early s he was a self-made millionaire, said Marr. After a night in King Tutrsquos in Glasgow he signed a popular beat combo by the name of Oasis. McGeersquos fame grew to the point where he was ldquowarmly embraced by the new, cool Britannia establishment led by Tony Blair. Cue *that* embarrassing footage of Noel Gallagher and McGee at a Downing Street reception.Another Scot makes an appearance in the final instalment, airing on December . Jimmy Reid is introduced as ldquothe shop steward with Elvis Presley hair.Marr recently named him as one of his top six New Elizabethans. He does not hide his admiration, telling viewers: ldquoJimmy Reid was one of the most compelling, charismatic and well-educated New Elizabethans of them all hellip He was determined to be a voice for the working classes and to recty what he saw as the deep injustices of British society.There is a clip from Reidrsquos famous ldquono bevvying speech and film of Billy Connolly, welder as was, turning up to show his support, as well as footage of the mass march to Glasgow Green.There are connections to Scotland where in the list, including Roy Jenkins, courtesy of his stint as MP for Hillhead, and the architect Zaha Hadid, the architectural visionary behind the Riverside Museum in Glasgow.Where Marr excelled was in creating a bigger picture, forging links through the ages. Thus a line was traced from Reid to Hadid via the Clyde, and from anti-nuclear campaigner Helen John to the march against the Iraq war.Surprisingly, given the title, the person least covered was the Queen herself. There were many shots of cheering crowds, though.Marr insisted there had been change in the monarchy, too. To film of the family on the balcony at Buckingham Palace, he says, ldquoIf you look carefully the Buckingham Palace balcony today seems a little less remote. Really Overall, a glitzy zip through seven decades with captivating footage and a poptastic soundtrack. As an alternative to The Crown I daresay Her Majesty will be delighted by it.
