title: funfair mum claire danter combats ptsd book writing
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClaire Danter and India Danter have teamed up to produce Nelson#s Funfair Holtspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtliday lt spangtlt spangt" Funfair mum Claire Danter combats PTSD with children#s book writingClaire Danter and India Danter have used their experiences in their book#s pltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtroductionlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA MUM from a travelling funfair family has traded on her experience of post-traumatic stress disorderto produce a childrenrsquos book available from Waterstones and Amazon.Claire Danter, writing under the name of Claire Carey, wrote Nelsons Funfair Holiday more than a year ago, having turned to writing as a form of therapy after she was attacked.Mrs Danter, , and husband James and sons James Jnr and Jonathan were part of the reopening of Barry Island Pleasure Park in  and stayed for three seasons.Her niece India Danter, who has illustrated the book, was born in Newport, moved to Caldicot and grew up on the funfair travelling around South Wales with her parents at Caldicot, Abergavenny, Cwmbran, Newport, and Cardf.Pleasure Park owners hit with order to stop calling ferris wheel the "Barry Eye"Barry Islands Ferris Wheel under threat due to planning disputePleasure Park rides due on site in three weeksMrs Danter said: ldquoMy journey to becoming a writer is the classic story of turning negative into positive.ldquoI started writing just after I suffered an attack - it was an unexpected vicious attack by another woman.ldquoAfter the attack I started to suffer from PTSD.ldquoI visited my doctor many times, how could I have PTSD ldquoI hadnt been to the front line.ldquoMy doctor told me it only takes one traumatic event or one moment when you believe your le could be lost.ldquoThe mental burden of PTSD is dreadful.ldquoI wouldnt wish that on anybody.ldquoIt has taken me over two years of my le to get to somewhere near normal and even now Im not the same person I was.ldquoThe writing was the escape I needed.ldquoWriting has aided my recovery so far and I would recommend this to anyone suffering from PTSD.ldquoAlthough Im left with the scars of PTSD, itrsquos is behind me now.ldquoWriting has now become a hobby for me and the sense of achievement - holding a published book in your hands that you have written is the best feeling.ldquoItrsquos great.Mrs Danter drew inspiration from a childrenrsquos book which she personally found horrying.ldquoI saw a childrens book called Dex and the Funfair by Paul Shipton.ldquoIn my opinion the story is shocking.ldquoEvenI wasnt part of the funfair industry myself, I wouldnt want my children to read such a book.ldquoThe worst part about this, is the book is fact that it is in some school libraries.The book details Dex smashing up a tin can alley stall and the stallholder giving Dex a prize to make him leave.ldquoThis is shocking on all levels, she said. ldquoAllowing children to read books like this at the age of five or six cannot be a good thing.ldquoMy second inspiration came when my nephew came on holiday with while we were on our travels, which in turn reminded me just how much fun it was growing up on the fairground.ldquoI decided to write Nelsons Funfair Holiday - a story about a little boy who goes to stay with his auntie who owns a funfair.ldquoThis story will give children a glimpse of what it is like visiting and growing up on the fairground.ldquoChildren in my opinion must have all the experiences le has to offer to broaden their minds ready for the wider world.ldquoTravelling fairgrounds are part of our heritage in the UK and across Europe.ldquoItrsquos our history, its who we are and we are all play a part in that, whether you grow up on the fairground or not.The Danters originally hail from Brynmawr.Goff Danter, an artist, was able to offer India tips and advice on illustrating the book which is her first having previously been commissioned to do pencil drawings under the trade name Romayne Art.Mrs Danter also has another book under her belt.Entitled Me and My Social Media, itrsquos a short, gripping story about the dark side of social media and how a perfectly normal family can be turned upside down.ldquoI am very proud of this book, she added. ldquoEverybody who reads it tells me they cannot put it until they have finished it.Nelsons Funfair Holiday costs pound. and is available from Amazon and Waterstones. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. ldquoThis has been a very long and dficult year for everyone."All our lives have been turned upside down by the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoEveryone has done so much to help control the spread of the virus and to save lives."But that has meant many sacrices, including not seeing family and close friends."We are all looking forward to Christmas and a chance to spend some time with all those we hold dear.ldquoToday, I met the First Ministers of Scotland and Northern Ireland and Michael Gove, from the UK Government, and Irsquom pleased we were able to agree a common four-nation plan for the festive period.MORE STORIESWhat you need to know about Cardf Bus Christmas travelHow to help brighten up Christmas on Barry Island boatsWho now qualies for  per cent off Morrisons groceries The text, of a joint statement issued by the four UK governments, said: As  draws to a close, we recognise it has been an incredibly dficult year for us all.We have all had to make signicant sacrices in our everyday lives, and many religious and community groups have already had to change or forgo their customary celebrations to slow the spread of coronavirus and save lives.This cannot be a lsquonormalrsquo Christmas.But as we approach the festive period, we have been working closely together to find a way for family and friends to see each other, evenit is for a short time, and recognising that it must be both limited and cautious.Even where it is within the rules, meeting with friends and family over Christmas will be a personal judgement for iniduals to take, mindful of the risks to themselves and others, particularly those who are vulnerable.We need everyone to think carefully about what they do during this period, balancing some increased social contact with the need to keep the risk of increased transmission of the virus as low as possible.This is particularly important when considering those who are vulnerable, and before deciding to come together over the festive period we urge the consideration of alternative approaches such as the use of technology or meeting outside.In this context, the four administrations have reached agreement on a single set of UK-wide measures to help people come together with their loved ones in a way that is as safe as possible.Today we have agreed that:bull Travel restrictions across the four administrations and between tiers will be lted to provide a window for households to come together between December  and December.bull Up to three households can form an exclusive lsquobubblersquo to meet at home during this period. When a bubble is formed it is fixed, and must not be changed or extended further at any point.bull Each Christmas bubble can meet at home, at a place of worship or an outdoor public place, but existing, more restrictive rules on hospitality and meeting in other venues will be maintained throughout this period.It is important that everyone respects and abides by the rules of each nation wherever they choose to spend the festive period.Where there are any iations in our approach, these will be communicated by each administration accordingly.Further guidance will be provided in due course.The winter holiday period is a time often spent with family and friends, with schools and offices closing and people travelling over the bank holidays.Many have already begun making their plans, and we are today providing clarity to help people make the right choices for them, and enjoy time with those closest to them while staying within the rules to protect us all. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: findings review penarth streets linked slavery
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityClive Place, Clive Crescent, and the Clive Arms Hotel were all deemed in the green category, meaning ldquopersons of interest are not commemorated.The review advises that while the names are associated with colonist Lord Robert Clive, they do not commemorate him.Plassey Street, which had been marked as another potential link to slavery, was not included in the audit review.The report was commissioned by First Minister Mark Drakeford in July in response to the death of George Floyd and the Black Lives Matter protests.Published yesterday, the audit was led by Gaynor Legall, and shows the slave trade was embedded in the Welsh economy and society and reflected in many statues, street and building names today.It identied  monuments, buildings or street names, located in all parts of Wales, which commemorate people who were directly involved with the slavery and the slave trade or opposed its abolition.The Vale council is carrying out its own review, with a deadline for suggested commemorations to be reviewed set for January .Hilary Brown, co-chairman of Stand Up To Racism Vale, which has been invited on the councilrsquos task board to discuss links to slavery in the region, said: ldquoItrsquos important to undertake an audit evenit is decided that no street or building names in the Vale should be removed. and Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" alt"Penarth Times: Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a review" class"editor-image"Vale protesters Bianca Aliand Hilary Brown at a protest calling for a reviewldquoWe feel it is important to teach everyone about the history of these names, and to tell the stories of how these names came to be. A separate discussion to that is what needs to be doneit is decided these names should not have been given in the first place.ldquoI would like to see the findings of the Welsh Government audit properly shared with the Vale council, prior to consultation with us.ldquoWe havenrsquot heard from the Vale council at all on this. We are waiting with baited breath for that to happen.Resident Nick Schroeter welcomed the findings of the review, saying: ldquoWe are talking about things that happened hundreds of years ago, and slavery is such a erse topic and has happened throughout history.ldquoIrsquom not saying itrsquos right, but I do believe we need to learn from it and move on.Stand Up To Racism protesters outside the Civic Offices, Barry, over the Valersquos connections to slaveryldquoEventhese road names were changed, people will still call them the same names. I feel especially during a pandemic these reviews are a waste of resources.Dinas resident Richard Winder added: ldquoThis generation needs to be aware of this stain on our history and to know of the terrible conditions on the slave ships and in the plantations, and also of the inhumanity of the gang masters and of the unimaginable obscenities of the punishments handed out.ldquoIf this means changing street names, moving statues, or educating as to how the money to build many of our great historic houses came from, then so be it.ldquoWe cannot change the past but we have the opportunity to do something positive to empathise with the feelings of our fellow countrymen, many of whom will have a history of slavery in their family long ago.The Vale council has been contacted for a response. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: covid vaccine rolled across wales coming days
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThis morning it was announced the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agencyhad authorised the first vaccine as safe and effective on the basis of detailed independent expert review of evidence from large scale clinical trials.The Pfizer Biontech vaccine has become the first to receive MHRA clearance in the UK and  million doses of the vaccine will shortly be available for delivery across the UK, with Wales getting its allocation based on population.Approval from the MHRA is the first step of Walesrsquo roll-out plan, which has seen preparations on-going since May.There are still a number of stages which need to happen before the vaccine reaches those in highest need and is ready for use, but this process is expected to happen over the next week.These stages includeThe Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationfinalising and publishing their guidance for the whole of the UKFinalising training materials for staff and patient information leafletsTraining of experienced immunisers for this particular vaccineFinal legal frameworks to allow registered health professionals to administer the vaccine to patients need to be authorised by each Health Board in Wales.The vaccine - which needs to be administered in two doses - will initially be prioritised and available for those aged  and over, care home staff and residents and those working within health and social care.As further supplies become available and additional vaccines receive MHRA approval, a staged approach will see other groups offered the vaccine, based on risk of serious complications and deaths.Iniduals in the priority groups for a Covid- vaccine will receive an invitation from their employer or health board, providing information about the vaccines, telling them where to go and what to do on the day of their appointment.People are urged to wait to be invited, and not to ask their pharmacist or GP.The chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoIt is fantastic to finally say that the first Covid- vaccine has been given the green light."We know now that we have a safe and effective vaccine for use across the UK - this is the positive news I and so many across the country have been waiting for.ldquoAll our NHS organisations across Wales have embraced the challenge presented to them and are at the advanced stages of planning for the arrival of a vaccine."We have tested distribution and storage arrangements to ensure we can get vaccine safely to every part of Wales.ldquoTherersquos still a few stages we need to work through but once all these safeguards are in place, vaccination can begin."There will only be relatively small amounts of the vaccine at first, those who have been advised as most needing the vaccine first, through approved delivery mechanisms."A full announcement around the timetable for roll-out in Wales will follow in the next few days.The effects of the vaccine may not be seen nationally for many months and the advice on keeping Wales safe remains the same for everyone, warned the first minister.Mark Drakeford said: "Todayrsquos news is a small glimmer of light at the end of what has been a long and dark tunnel.ldquoWe know some people within our communities are much more at risk than others from the serious complications of Covid-, which is why the new vaccine is being prioritised to protect them first.ldquoWhilst these first doses are given at fixed sites and occupational settings, and to protect our NHS and social care services, we must all continue to do our bit to prevent the spread of coronavirus: regular hand washing, social distancing, and wearing a face covering where required to protect yourself and others.Pfizer Biontech vaccine needs to be stored at ultra-low temperatures. These centres have already been decided by health boards and are in the process of being prepared.The development process for coronavirus vaccines has been as stringent as any other but the process in the face of the pandemic has been sped up by prompt, world-wide funding and a reduction in paperwork.Theof the trials have not been shortened, and the usual safety measures remain in place.The vaccine will not be mandatory and people will be able to choose whether they take up the vaccine or not.Information will be provided to people before vaccination to reassure them about patient safety and robust consent processes will be in place.Vice-chairman of the Covid- Vaccine Programme Board, Richard Roberts from Public Health Wales, said: ldquoIt is a signicant achievement that only  months after WHOannounced the global pandemic that we now have the first safe and effective vaccine available for use in Wales, and other vaccines to follow."Everyone has been preparing for months to deliver the Covid- vaccine programme, and it is very exciting that we will be able to begin, once the final steps have been put in place so that the programme can be delivered safely. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: lucky get one penarth pubs closing due covid rules
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe news comes after new coronavirus restrictions were announced on Monday.Pubs, restaurants and cafes will be banned from selling alcohol from Friday and will be unable to open to customers beyond pm.Announcing the news first minister Mark Drakeford said the new restrictions will help tackle a rise in coronavirus cases.But publicans reacted in unison to the news to condemn the latest rule changes, saying many pubs and bars will be left with almost nothing when the financial year comes to an end in the spring, and loans have to be repaidcoinciding with the end of the furlough scheme.David Cole, part owner of Gin  at Victoria Road, said he was expecting restrictionsbut says he was stunned at the severity of the new rules.David ColeldquoI was anticipating they would allow us to open until pm and serve alcohol, which would have hurt us but at least it would have been something ndash but these restrictions mean we canrsquot operate at all after Friday until theyrsquore lted, said Mr Cole.ldquoWe would be lucky to get one customer a day.Mr Drakeford said firms hit by the restrictions would be offered poundm in support which he claimed was "the most generous package" anywhere in the UK.Mr Cole added: ldquoIrsquom very concerned we will lose signicant revenue ndash itrsquos undoubtedly the busiest time of the year for us.ldquoI understand there needs to be restrictions, but in the lead up to Christmas are we really expecting these changes will make people stop socialising ldquoI think it will increase the numbers of illegal gatherings, and therersquoll be no one around to remind people to socially distance. I wouldnrsquot be surprised to see a spike in cases as a result of this decision.All pub and bar owners that spoke to the Penarth Times said they are concerned about what happens after the next review on December , with the majority saying they do not believe pubs will be able to serve alcohol until January.Health minister Vaughan Gething said he understood why companies in the industry are upset, but admitted there is "no perfect balance" between protecting public health and businesses.Health minister Vaughan GethingBut Brains CEO Alistair Darby told the Penarth Times he feels the government has got the balance wrong.Brains pubs including the Windsor and the Star Inn in Dinas Powys will close on Friday.ldquo, people have come through our doors since the start of the pandemic ndash seven staff members have tested positive in that time and test and trace have contacted us five times, said Mr Darby.ldquoI wonrsquot question the science behind the government decision, but it seems to me wersquove shown what wersquove done has worked.ldquoWersquove worked tirelessly to make sure people are as safe as possible in our pubs, and people have been safe. Our findings show that.ldquoThe scarring effect this will have on the economy will be brutal and long drawn out. We have already been operating at a  per cent deficit compared to .ldquoWersquore a business that is well run, looks after its workers, pays its taxes and contributes a lot to the economy to support the NHS.ldquoIrsquom aware there has to be a balance. But itrsquos imperative we donrsquot crush our economy in the process. I think this time that balance has not been achieved.John Bassett, who owns The Golden Lion on Glebe Street which will also be closed, said: ldquoAre they going to say we can open for Christmas after this  Irsquod be surprised.John BassettldquoIrsquom resigned to an awful period financially ndash my only focus now is to try and keep all  of my staff. I havenrsquot laid any of my staff off yet, and donrsquot intend to, but this is really becoming testing for us now.ldquoYet again we received hardly any notice before this comes into effect. I would question how the whole industry has been treated throughout this period.ldquoMark Drakeford says he talks to stakeholders ndash yet I know nobody who has ever had a conversation with a representative of the Welsh Government on this issue.Natasha Rees, new landlady at St Fagans on Windsor Road, has worked tirelessly since she took the pub over in the autumn to make it a family friendly place. She says she is most concerned about the impact on her customers.Natasha with her family before they left the Station Hotel in Cogan earlier this yearldquoIrsquom going to do everything I can until Friday to make sure we wave them off for Christmas in a way that keeps their spirits up, she said.ldquoI have no choice but to close, and I think wersquoll be closed until January. Itrsquos horrible, wersquore right in the heart of the town and I feel wersquove made great strides to bring a community feel back here. Itrsquos a big blow for me but I feel mostly for them .ldquoMost of them come to have a chat, not to drink, but the reality is we wonrsquot be able to sell enough soft drinks to warrant staying open.The Railway Hotel also confirmed it will be closing until further notice.The Welsh Government were contacted for further comment but failed to respond.The Christmas edition of Gin s Penarth Gin is a small batch edition they have produced for the festive season. title: converted victorian baths penarth can
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityNows your chance with this exceptional luxury flat inside a converted Victorian municipal baths in Penarth, which is on the market for pound,,.This Grade II listed building is on Balmoral Quay and the three-bedroom seafront apartment is currently on the market with Martin  Co, Cardf  Merthyr Tydfil.The former baths date back to  when the building was originally created for public bathing. The Victorian baths, which featured two salt water pools, closed its doors almost a century later and was then turned into a pub restaurant, before being converted into four separate apartments in .The property still maintains a lot of its original features including the brickwork and windows of the original baths, as well as steel beams and a beautul glass lantern roof for the ceiling.The interior of the apartment has been given a contemporary upgrade to help give the flat a more luxurious finish.The apartment has its own private spa, including a Jacuzzi, sauna, steam room, shower area and a bathroom. It is also has a mezzanine gym area, which sits on a balcony overlooking the spa on the ground floor.The three bedrooms have beautul brickwork and wooden flooring ndash making them minimalist but radiating Victorian charm. The apartment also benefits from two bathrooms.The main living area has the original arched windows and stunning exposed brick work walls, as well as a log burner which makes it perfect for those chilly winter evenings.The kitchen comes with all of the modern features you could need, including washing machine, dishwasher, a coffee machine and even a Liebherr wine chiller.On the upper mezzanine is a home office - a large open plan space with the glass lantern ceiling and stunning original steel beams.Henry Mitchell, director at Martin  Co Cardf  Merthyr Tydfil said: "This apartment is unique with its history of being a Victorian municipal baths conversion."The built-in-spa and original brickwork and windows ensures the property is in keeping with the history of the building but it still maintains a modern design. The open plan living, and large windows, bring in a lot of light, which really opens up the space."The property is also close to Penarth pier and esplanade as well at the town centre.This property is on the market with Martin  Co, Cardf  Merthyr Tydfil.
